channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Israel crush: Netanyahu promises inquiry as first victims are buried
item.description: A crush at a Jewish festival kills 45 people in one of the country's worst disasters.

item.title: Actor Noel Clarke says sorry but denies sexual misconduct
item.description: The actor denies wrongdoing but says some of his actions "affected people in ways I did not intend".

item.title: Covid-19 infections in UK back to late summer levels - ONS
item.description: The ONS estimates infections are 20 times lower than at the peak in January with 0.1% infected.

item.title: Mars Ingenuity helicopter mission extended by Nasa
item.description: Nasa is so pleased with the success of the Ingenuity helicopter it is extending its mission.

item.title: Julia James: Family tributes to killed community police officer
item.description: Community police officer Julia James was "naturally funny with a brilliant sense of humour".

item.title: Game of Thrones actress sues Marilyn Manson alleging abuse
item.description: Game of Thrones actress Esmé Bianco accuses the singer of rape and sexual battery.

item.title: Jimi Olubunmi-Adewole: Thames rescuer nominated for bravery award
item.description: Police say 'it is absolutely right' to recognise the heroism of Folajimi Olubunmi-Adewole.

item.title: Covid: UK clubbers return to Liverpool for trial night
item.description: Thousands return to the dance floor in Liverpool at a test event with no social distancing or masks.

item.title: Met PC sacked for hitting vulnerable teenage girl with baton 34 times
item.description: PC Benjamin Kemp also used CS spray after unsuccessfully trying to handcuff the teenager.

item.title: Giant 300-tonne fatberg blocks Birmingham sewer
item.description: Severn Trent says the mass of oil, grease and "unflushable" items could take until June to clear.

item.title: McDonald's robber who demanded chicken nuggets jailed
item.description: Rudi Batten was denied chicken nuggets but fled with a double-sausage McMuffin and some cash.

item.title: Crowland WWII tank recovered after 74 years underground
item.description: The vehicle is in "fantastic" condition despite its subterranean stay says the man behind the dig.

item.title: Swimming with my stoma bag
item.description: Gill Castle is on a mission to break down fear and stigma around taking to the water with a colostomy pouch.

item.title: 'Disaster Girl' sells iconic meme for £340,000
item.description: Zoë Roth, 21, will use the money from the sale of a 2005 image of her to pay her student loan.

item.title: Cornholme erotic books note attacks 'cesspit' Hebden Bridge
item.description: A village goes viral when an angry note appears on its book-swap box railing against "filthy" titles.

item.title: Bronze Age treasure found in Swedish forest by mapmaker
item.description: A man stumbled on ancient jewellery while surveying a forest for his orienteering club.

item.title: Line of Duty finale: Obsessed podcaster Craig Parkinson - 'I've gone so deep forensically'
item.description: Craig Parkinson, who played DI "Dot" Cotton, is interrogated by BBC Breakfast. Will he crack?

item.title: These people aren't real but could help tackle bias in tech
item.description: How technology that generates fake faces is helping to tackle bias in facial recognition systems.

item.title: 'Heartbreaking' return to St Vincent's volcano-hit 'red zone'
item.description: A teacher returns to a village in St Vincent's restricted, volcano-damaged 'red zone'.

item.title: World's longest pedestrian suspension bridge to open in Portugal
item.description: Local residents tested out the 500m walkway, which spans a gorge in Portugal's Arouca Geopark.

item.title: Israel crush: Witnesses tell of people 'thrown up in the air'
item.description: Those at the Lag B'Omer festival, where dozens died, say they were "swept along" by the crowd.

item.title: Xueli Abbing: The abandoned baby who became a Vogue model
item.description: The 16-year-old's albinism led to her being abandoned as a baby but she is now a successful model.

item.title: Boris Johnson flat row: What do we know about the PM’s finances?
item.description: With controversy over the Downing Street flat redecoration, how much does the prime minister earn?

item.title: How a tribute band inspired Royal Blood's new music
item.description: Frontman Mike Kerr says he ditched dozens of songs after watching tribute act Royal Monster in 2018.

item.title: 'It's your device, you should be able to repair it'
item.description: The BBC talks to the volunteers running free workshops to help consumers fix broken gadgets.

item.title: Australians stuck overseas 'abandoned' by their own country
item.description: Australians in India are the latest group to feel abandoned by their government amid virus fears.

item.title: The ransomware surge ruining lives
item.description: A coalition is calling for action from governments as victims describe crippling cyber-attacks.

item.title: India Covid: A nurse's story of fighting the virus
item.description: A nurse at the forefront of the battle against India's deadly second Covid wave shares her story.

item.title: Champions League hopefuls Leicester held by 10-man Southampton
item.description: Southampton hold Leicester to a draw despite playing more than 80 minutes with 10 men to frustrate the Foxes in their push to seal a top-four finish.

item.title: England win as floodlight failure forces abandonment of match in France - highlights & report
item.description: Women's Six Nations champions England's Test in France is called off in the 63rd minute after the floodlights fail.

item.title: Leicester sink Ulster with stunning fightback to reach European Challenge Cup final
item.description: Leicester Tigers reach the Challenge Cup final after a sensational second half comeback sees them battle past Ulster with a 33-24 win.

item.title: 'Joshua v Fury is not dead in the water' - Hearn responds to Arum claims
item.description: Promoter Eddie Hearn says claims a bout between Anthony Joshua and Tyson Fury is "dead in the water" are not true.

item.title: Ian Wright and Alan Shearer discuss the impact of racist online abuse
item.description: Ian Wright sits down with Alan Shearer to discuss the effect of racist abuse online and shows him an abusive direct message he received that morning.

item.title: Five things we learned from the leaders' debate in Wales
item.description: The TV crunch match could help decide the outcome of the election, but there was no knockout blow.

item.title: 2021 elections: What elections can I vote in this year?
item.description: National elections in Scotland and Wales and local elections in England are scheduled for 6 May 2021.

item.title: Elections 2021: Teenage Welsh voters' hopes for historic first vote
item.description: Teenage voters in Wales tell BBC Radio 5 Live how they feel about voting for the first time.

item.title: Elections 2021: How to follow the results on the BBC
item.description: Find out how to keep up to date with live election results on TV, radio, online and on social media.

item.title: Election 2021: PCC role in spotlight amid Bristol protests
item.description: What do young voters in Bristol know about about the role of the police and crime commissioner?

item.title: London Elections 2021: Top tasks facing the next mayor
item.description: The next mayor will run a £19bn budget and head London's key institutions.

item.title: 2021 elections: A simple guide to the Scottish, Welsh and local elections
item.description: A bumper crop of elections are being held on 6 May across England, Scotland and Wales.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Northern Ireland is the latest part of the UK to lift some of the restrictions designed to stop the spread of Covid-19.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People 40 or over in England are now being offered a Covid vaccine as the rollout continues.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's happening with pools, haircuts and gyms?
item.description: Lockdown has been eased further - but what does it mean for hairdressers, pools and gyms?

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 34 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: When can I holiday abroad and where is on the green and red lists?
item.description: A so-called "green list" of countries is being drawn up where quarantine won't be required when you return to the UK.

item.title: Covid: Can you catch the virus outside?
item.description: The risks of catching Covid indoors are well-known, but what are the chances of being infected outdoors?

item.title: What are the Indian, Brazil, South Africa and UK variants?
item.description: Cases are being found in the UK and the changes the virus is undergoing are concerning.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and can I hold a reception?
item.description: Restrictions on weddings have been eased across the UK - but big celebrations with lots of guests are some way off.

item.title: Why India's Covid crisis matters to the whole world
item.description: The situation in India is a bleak reminder that none of us will be safe until everyone is safe.
